question: Match the following (Gymnosperm basics):
column_II: Not enclosed by any ovary wall and remain exposed, both before and after fertilisation
Medium-sized trees or tall trees and shrubs
matches: Ovule nature in gymnosperms–Not enclosed by any ovary wall and remain exposed, both before and after fertilisation
Growth form of gymnosperms–Medium-sized trees or tall trees and shrubs
answer: Ovule nature in gymnosperms–Not enclosed by any ovary wall and remain exposed, both before and after fertilisation, Seed covering in gymnosperms–Not covered, Example of gymnosperm–Sequoia, Growth form of gymnosperms–Medium-sized trees or tall trees and shrubs, Reproductive adaptation–Wind-pollinated

question: Match the following (Gymnosperm roots & stems):
column_I: Stem type in Pinus and Cedrus
matches: Stem type in Pinus and Cedrus–Branched
answer: Root type in gymnosperms–Tap roots, Fungal association in Pinus roots–Mycorrhiza, Specialised roots in Cycas–Coralloid roots, Stem type in Cycas–Unbranched, Stem type in Pinus and Cedrus–Branched

question: Match the following (Gymnosperm leaves & adaptations):
column_I: Water loss prevention in conifer leaves
column_II: Well-adapted to withstand extremes of temperature, humidity and wind
matches: Gymnosperm leaf persistence–Persist for a few years
Leaf adaptation to extreme conditions–Well-adapted to withstand extremes of temperature, humidity and wind
Surface area reduction in conifers–Needle-like leaves
Water loss prevention in conifer leaves–Thick cuticle and sunken stomata
answer: Leaf type in Cycas–Pinnate leaves, Gymnosperm leaf persistence–Persist for a few years, Leaf adaptation to extreme conditions–Well-adapted to withstand extremes of temperature, humidity and wind, Surface area reduction in conifers–Needle-like leaves, Water loss prevention in conifer leaves–Thick cuticle and sunken stomata
